I miss that fragrance, and it's one that you don't find in your regular sliced bread.  The noodles were overcooked though, which was unfortunate.    I really wish I had known that the "taco bao" wasn't actually some fusion attempt at putting cheese and ground meat into a steamed bun, but instead what sounds like a delicious slice of pork belly.    It's casual dining.  You order up front and bus your own tables.  The decor is cute and reminds me of a trendy Taiwan place if it were half the size with the same number of tables.

The food here is absolutely amazing! Try the haus noodle soup with pork, the haus sticker & xiao long bao (soup dumplings) - you won't be disappointed! In addition to the delicious food the staff is very friendly and service is quick! I will definitely be back & highly recommend that you come & try it out!
Yummy food, but on the pricy side and if you prefer meatless prepare to order ala carte...still worth it cause its dee-lish.

Had the worst experience here and I would never come back again. Dumplings, wontons, buns, etc. are very easy food to make but it tasted terrible here. If you are Asian you might just feel offended. The broth was bland. Nothing had flavors at all.

Pretty solid, straightforward, inoffensive Chinese dumplings. Would recommend.   The quality of the food is great. The buns and dumplings hit all the major sort of flavors that you'd expect from this sort of Beijing or Hong Kong style of meat+dough, but doesn't do much more than that.   One thing I'd comment about is that there's a bit of a strange, machine-like consistency to their dishes. Like all of their dishes have been made a little too identically? The noodles in their beef noodle soup don't have much "personality" in terms of texture and the flavors of the soup and dumplings don't have anything particularly bold to them. But honestly, that's not too bad on occasion. It's not the kind of place you'd go to try to get "authentic" or whatever and that's fine. I'm trying to avoid flexing my Chinese-upbringing on this review and say "these things should be like blah blah blah". There's a lot of dissent on these things, even within my friends and family. For the local market, you'd want that general appeal.   It's good food and is the most casual place to eat in the area, especially if you don't want to commit to sitting down and eating. The price is what you'd expect from this sort of upscale-ish place without the labor market of a big city, so don't expect a real deal. But the food is decent and more interesting than the usual pub fare.   Sometimes you just want a meat bun, and that's okay.

Stopped in and ordered a take our order for 2.   25 minutes later I was checking in with them, and they said it was almost ready. 3 other parties that came in at least 20-25' after me received their order. I checked in a total of 3 times in 45' and they claimed 40' is what I should expect for steamed dumpling/potstickers.   Still took 10 more minutes.   Not much of an apology....

First thing's first: Dumpling Haus is located in Hilldale Mall, so make sure you don't drive past it looking for a standalone restaurant. Now for the review:  When you first walk into Dumpling Haus, you are greeted by a clean, modern, but not pretentious atmosphere. The chalkboard menu obove the counter is fairly big but also straight forward: it's just noodles, dumplings, and a few other dim sum items) If you look straight from the door, you may see somebody making dumplings by hand (so you know that they're fresh). However, you may or may not be greeted by the person at the counter; she may never make eye contact with you even while placing your order. Manners aren't terribly important to me if the food is good, but it should be noted.  We ordered xiao long bao soup dumplings, shrimp dumplings, black bean pork noodles (because it sounded similar to korean black bean noodles, jiajang men), and sesame kick (because it sounded similar to dan dan noodles). After ordering, we brought water and sauces to our table since it's self service.  The food came out pretty quickly, but it wasn't good. Both noodles had no texture to them and very little flavor. The shrimp dumplings had a fragile, mushy texture to it with very little flavor. The xiao long bao was ok. Maybe I ordered the wrong things, but the food did not live up to my friends' recommendations.  Since the menu is so big, I'm going to have to come back. I really want to like this place.

Great dumplings and noodles and friendly staff. Last time we were there we had red bean paste and egg custard dumplings, both delicious.  It's difficult to find good Chinese food in Madison, so I am happy I found this place!

I love Dumpling Haus! My favorites are the peanut glazed noodles (I usually order them warm, with extra veggies) and the veggie bao. Both items are vegan, ordered normally. The peanut noodles are very saucy, and the sauce is flavorful without being overwhelming. The buns come with deliciously prepared greens (spinach, or maybe bok choy, or both?) and are served with a yummy and light tangy sauce.They have several other vegan options, too, like the sesame kick noodles (my boyfriend's favorite,) veggie wontons, veggie fried rice, veggie potstickers, and veggie lo mein (and possibly others I have not tried or asked about). I did not care for the lo mein, as it was too garlicky for my taste, but my boyfriend liked it. It's a great place to go for a quick lunch or dinner, or we get takeout there and it usually only takes 15 minutes. Definitely recommend this place!

If you're looking for super amazing flavorful brothy noodles and soup, this place can be a bit deceiving...  Their location and atmosphere is not bad at all! But when we got our food, it was actually quite a disappointment. Not much flavor quite frankly in any of the 3 things we got: BBQ Pork buns, Xiao Long Bao, and Pork Cabbage Soup and Noodles.  The pork buns were very bland with not much aroma-ful flavor to it, and the pork cabbage soup just didn't taste as juicy and savory as one would imagine it to be just by looking at it. The Xiao Long Baos were probably the best out of the three - there is soup inside the dumplings, which make it juicy. But honestly, the wrapping was still sort of stiff and the inside was pretty plain. I know that Xiao Long Baos are hard to make, so I'll give credit to them for making it as good as they could make it. But still.. overall the eating experience here was not up to my standard! And I've eaten at numerous noodle and Asian restaurants. Would I go here again... unfortunately probably not :(
My absolute favorite dumplings. They're always delicious and service is very good. Their new location is super nice too!
It took over 45 minutes to be served a bowl of noodles in sauce. The sesame kick noodles were advertised as being spicy, but were very bland. $8 for a bowl of noodles in sauce is too much.

Not bad! The dumplings remind me of stuff I might be able to get at home. I ordered their classic potstickers and a bowl of pork noodles. These are done in in the Chinese style - the dumplings have thicker skins and are pan-fried, while the soup noodle has thicker noodles, clearer and cleaner broth, and pork with bone. I will say the noodles could have been more savory, even if it's a soy sauce-based broth. The dumplings were really nice though, well-seared with a good crunchy base, and the meat filling has a nice savory helping of pork and veggies. It's probably the closest thing to real potstickers I've gotten in Madison yet. (It helped that I was able to speak Chinese to them, and they had vinegar which is the traditional sauce that goes with potstickers.)  If there's a life lesson to be drawn, it's that you should get dumplings when the place is called DumplingHaus.

Not a bad place for a first timer looking to try dim sum. The menu is pretty straight forward I don't remember seeing anything that would be unappetizing to a first timer (chicken feet). Even though I like chicken feet. But anyway... It was very easy to order and the prices were very reasonable. I spent $40 for me and a friend and we were full. Me and him eat like pigs so the portions are good in that aspect. I don't fully remember what we had but it was all good. The shrimp dumplings and a pork dish were all very good. The beef curry dumplings were ok. What really surprised me was the fried rice. It's was very light and flavorful but wasn't plain and boring. The rice and other ingredients seemed to be fresh as well. The place is clean and feels more like a cafe than a restaurant. It's a great place to experience dim sum for the first time and I would definitely go back to try more.

My first visit experience was Five stars! But I really wanna try another menu before give them five stars. I had BBQ Bao and it was good. I also had Blackbean & Pork noodle bowl, it was soon good! Fair price, vegetarian menu, clean place and friendly host. I highly recommend this place for everyone!

Slightly out of our comfort zone but glad we decided to give this place a try. We ordered pork dumplings and their chicken fried rice. Both were very tasty and fresh. Looking forward to trying them again soon!

Okay, I REALLY wanted to like this place! I am always looking for somewhere to get fresh, flavorful dishes...but I just felt like this was a bit of a miss.   I ordered the Seasonal Harvest noodles with the add on of 4 haus dumplings. The noodle dish is vegetarian and changes depending on the veggies available. I am A-OK with vegetarian dishes, but not flavorless ones. This seriously tasted like plain noodles in water with carrots and bok choy. That's it. There was no seasoning whatsoever. The veggies were fresh and nice...but I was glad that I had gotten the dumplings(which were decent, but not amazing) to supplement. The melon green tea was refreshing, and sadly, my favorite part of the meal.   The man got the pork potstickers which, again, were okay but not amazing.   I agree with the comment that prices seemed high. The noodles were around $9 with the mini order of dumplings an additional $3.50. Considering the fact that I left half my noodles(and not because I was full), it was spendy.   I would like to go again and try the bao, and maybe a different noodle dish. Like I said, I REALLY wanted to like it. I hope to get the chance to update with an improved review in the future.  *And as far as the review from C.L. about ordering non-dumplings from a place called "Dumpling Haus", I don't think that a place called the "Chicken Shack" has an excuse for having a crappy steak, if they choose to put a steak on the menu.   If dumplings are the only thing you do well, then maybe you need to just stick to dumplings.

A little confusing for first-timers. The menu is written on chalk boards and is tough to tell how many of each come in an order, whether it's dumplings, bao, or wontons. We ordered what I thought was a reasonable amount of food, but what we got left my wife and I still feeling a bit unsatisfied.   Overall the quality was good. We had the pork dumplings, haus bao, and cream cheese wontons. The noodle bowls that we spied at other tables looked good as well. Service was fast, which was nice.   I would rate Dumpling Haus as average. Good food, but not good enough to get me to make a special trip to Hilldale just for the dumplings.
I have the pork dumpling which is really pretty good it was fried with a nice brown crust . is a little bit on the pricey side for what you get but otherwise pretty good

Really solid place.  I'm typically pretty biased in my judgement of Chinese cuisine but this place gets a thumbs up from me.  In addition to the standard dumpling potstickers and bao zhi you'd see in a big city China Town, this place also has some really great authentic noodle and soup dishes.  My wife and I had the chicken lo mein and it was as good as my mom's!  As others have noted, the prices are a bit steep but they must have to have higher prices to cover the costs of the premium location in Hilldale.  Still, it's a great weekend spot or place to grab lunch on a weekday.

Pretty good place in Hilldale mall! Very unassuming because it's very authentic Chinese food in a mall area and it was pretty packed when we came on a Friday evening and waited about an hour from walking in to eating (so expect long lines and don't have anywhere to go afterwards!). The soup dumplings are delicious albeit very small and pricey. We also tried two noodle soups that had very light flavor and tasted very healthy. The noodles were good but I personally felt like it was something I could have made at home: flavor was light and a little lacking. However, the beef slices in them were excellent. Tender and succulent and all around delicious.   Overall, a pretty pricey place for what it is, but the food is tasty.

I must have had a really high expectation. We ordered the Haus noodle soup and black bean and pork noodles. They were both 80% noodles 10% meat and 10% others. Although the noodle soup has more meat. The haus stickers taste weird as well. I also ordered the custard baos and they were not that good either. They have really good bao dough though. So if you like baos, come here. Dont come here for noodles, u'd be disappointed.

The dumplings and boas were really good, but the pork and bean noodles were enough to drop to three stars.  It was gelatinous, flavorless, and there was no sign of black beans.  Reminded me of the corn starch laden food at the crappy Chinese restaurants.

This is a decent place for dumplings. The service was pretty fast and friendly. What more can you ask for?  The wrappers sucked for their xiao long baos because they easily fall apart and you'd lose a lot of the soup, but if you're careful enough to not have it break apart on you, the taste is actually pretty decent. It's not DIn Tai Fung good, but it's good for Madison. I feel like you kind of have to lower your standards for most Asian food when you're out in the Midwest; I'm okay with it as long as it's edible. The dipping sauce isn't quite what I expected either, but it's decent enough. They'd do much better if they can buy a decent bottle of Chinese black vinegar and just add in a few pieces of raw ginger strips. It's also quite expensive for such tiny dumplings (quite smaller than what you'd normally get at other Chinese restaurants) at 8 dumplings for $7. However, I will note that I'm not sure if there are other restaurants in Madison that sells these (as this is the only Chinese restaurant I've tried so far in this city).  We also got to try their egg custard buns. This was also pretty decent, but they don't taste all that much different from ones that I'd buy frozen from Asian grocery stores, so I can't really justify buying this here. Four buns for $5 is a bit expensive.   We also tried their noodles in black bean sauce (listed as black bean and pork noodles). Believe it or not, I've actually never tried the Chinese version of this dish; I've only had the Korean version. I thought theirs was pretty decent as well. I'd have wanted the noodles to be able to pick up the sauce better though.   The Haus noodle soup was the most disappointing dish for me. This is their take on the Chinese beef noodle soup, and it tasted very bland to me. Not only did it taste bland, the beef was also overcooked so it was a bit tough. They also chopped up their bak choy in small bite-size pieces, which I found very strange. Perhaps this is what their clientele wants, but it's not what I'm used to and I just find it unnecessary.   Would I come back? Probably not. In short, go ahead and order the noodles in black bean sauce, but that's it. Everything else is not good or extremely overpriced.

We ordered chicken lo mein, pot stickers, pork wontons, and siu mai, but only the lo mein is acceptable.  The other food tastes no better than the frozen food you can buy from a supermarket.  Never come here.

Ever since visiting Taiwan years ago, I have not found a dumpling or steam fun worthy of that region. Until now. Along the lines of Din Tai Fung this has to be the best steamed bun restaurant I have been to since timeline. The Buns were soft filled correctly and yummy yummy yummy.
It sucks that the dumplings stick to the pan, but they are super delicious. One order isn't a lot of food but that is OK since you're eating lunch here

Awesome bao and noodles!  This is a place I frequent and recommend to people all the time.  I highly recommend: 1. Haus bao- filling is really flavorful and the bun is the best combo of soft and warm. Like a hug from your mom. 2. Haus pot stickers 3. Noodle Kick Everything I've tried has been really good, these just happen to be my go to favorites  The service can be slow at times, especially if you go at peak hours (weekends at dinner time).   This is totally an aside, but one of the employees can add up your order (with tax) faster than I can think. I am impressed by this everytime.

I just moved here and wanted to try something that reminded me of Chicago.  I ordered the Xiao long nap....soup dumplings. These were so hot when they came out. I had to let them sit so I didn't burn my tongue. The sauce for it was ok.   I also ordered the black bean and pork noodles. This was pretty filling and I was able to take half of it home for lunch the next day. The sauce was not too salty and it had just the right amount of fresh green onions and cucumber slices on top.   This is a smaller place and probably not the best for extra large groups. You can serve yourself water. You'll have to ask for forks if you need them but they only offer chopsticks next to the water counter.   There is also outdoor seating...a couple of tables.   I'm definitely going back for the Xiao long bao!

This place is quite authentic. It's sort of took me back to China in a way, you don't get that much in Madison! Soup dumplings were very good. The noodles were on the light side but the flavor was not bad. They are slightly pricey and it can add up but I think it's worth it. The family that ran the place was really nice

Dumpling Haus is great compared to your other options in Madison.  It provides a nice solid choice but I cannot say that is the best when compared to all the other dumplings I've had over the course of my life in other cities!  Got the...  nutella buns- you can't really go wrong with nutella. so this was a tasty treat  Haus Noodle Soup- it was good but didn't have a amazing quality about it that would make me want to order it again  Xiao Long Bao- these were my favorite among what I got. I'm a big fan of soup dumplings. These aren't the best I've ever had but if I were craving some I would come to dumpling haus to get them.  It's a cute shop, all those steam from the dumpling making make the windows of the restaurant front steam up like crazy!

It seems to be Madison's only real dumpling offering in the Dim Sum category if Chinese and Asian style dumplings.   I've sampled versions menu items on various occasions. This place is the only place I know of for at least 100 plus miles where when can get a steamed pork bun. I've enjoyed the pork buns but found I prefer the steamed curry bun. The pork buns are good, but tend to be a little too sweet.   I've also sampled a variety of the dumplings. They are OK but seem to be a bit inconsistent, if not bland in there preparation. I also find the space itself can be hot... As in warm environmentally.  The service is pretty decent for what it is - you order at the counter and get a little table number to display.   I'd like to go back and continue to explore the menu. It's quick and inexpensive. The servings come in multiples, so it's a good place to explore the me use with 2, 3 or 4 people.

The Xio Long Bao is amazing here. Nice little dumplings that have a great tasty pop of soup as you bite into the dumpling. Only place that I know of where you can get these in Madison. Their soups are also very tasty and delicious. The owners are supper nice, they will split the soup for you if they know you are sharing it. Hands down best place in town to settle your cravings for quick, easy, tasteful dumplings or soup.

If you are looking for a no-fuss, quality spot for some of the best dumplings in town (from literally the nicest old man owner in the entirety of Madison), head on over to DumplingHaus.    I have been enjoying their house dumplings since they were located across the street inside Hilldale Mall. Their portions are relatively large; I would recommend three entrees for two people and then treating the food like tapas.   When I'm in the mood for something a little bit heartier, I will get their cold peanut noodle dish, which is essentially thick noodle, peanut sauté, freshly sliced cucumbers and crushed peanuts.   The interior looks like a scene out of Zoey 101 (a reference for all of my millennials out there), meaning that I would not call DumplingHaus a place of authenticity, but rather somewhere along the lines of funky.

Hands down the best Chinese in Madison!! Just happened to discover it after I was done shopping in Macy's.. Love the food here!! Must try shrimp wanton soup,dumplings,lo mien,fried rice!! I have tried Chinese before but i was never happy but this one stands out!!

Let's start by stating unequivocally that the dumplings, bao zi and noodle bowls are nothing short of fantastic. The meats appear to be high quality with none of the nasty, low-quality cuts that bring down the ratings of so many Asian restaurants. The vegetables are fresh and when combined with meats to create their fillings, complement each other fantastically. The place is squeaky clean and the staff is friendly and thorough in describing the entrees for customers with questions. Dumpling Haus falls short of a 5-star rating only because (1) the ordering system is inefficient with just one register, which resulted in a long wait behind dine-in customers while my takeout sat on the counter getting cold; and (2) the quantity you receive for the price leaves even my young kids still hungry after paying $9 or more for an order. I highly recommend checking it out if you have a little extra time on your hands and money in your pocket.

Ate here for lunch while shopping at Hilldale.  I was with another person and shared an order of pan-fried Haus dumplings. These were excellent and I would definitely come back to try other dishes. Dumplings are made fresh and you can definitely taste it. The only thing that I would change would be the ordering method. The restaurant had menus that you would expect at a full-service place, but there was no formal seating or waiter service. I would recommend a menu board that explains dishes better instead of having those available at the front. But that is a very minor detail. Go and check out this place!

PROS: Best dumplings in Madison, I daresay CONS: Slightly pricier than expected  Self-service, order-at-the-counter type of venue. Tasty, authentic, made-to-order Beijing-style dumplings. Okay sesame noodles. I will definitely be back for more dumplings in the future.

Tried the Dumpling Haus for the first time today for a late lunch.  So, so delicious!  We started with the pork steamed dumplings (forgot name), then I had the Sesame Noodle Kick and my husband had the Pork Lo Mein, we finished off with the steamed buns with the red bean paste for some dessert.  This ended up being quite a bit of food, but I'm proud to say we ate it all!  I loved the open feeling of the restaurant and being able to watch all the food being made.  Service was great too - every table was full and people kept rolling in, but the employees were very efficient and the wait for our food was not long.  All our food tasted fresh and everything had great flavor.

So-so fully Americanized "Asian" food at Hilldale prices.  The Haus Noodle Soup was ok, but after eating at Saigon Noodles or Hong Kong Station, you'll really wish you were having soup there, rather than here.  My kid had the Lo Mein and all I could taste when I tried it was salt.  Dumplings were pedestrian.  I've eaten here 2-3 time previously (focusing on buns and dumplings) and it was all forgettable.  Reminds me of the "Chinese Restaurants" in mid-Missouri that I thought were awesome when I was a kid, before I knew what good Asian food tasted like.

Xiao Long Bao is fine. I will give 3.5 out of 5. And the cold noodle(I forget it's name) is good.   This restaurant is in Hilldale Mall and is very easy to be found. People are friendly in there.  Actually this is my first time in Madison and this makes me recall the life in China.

I love the concept of the Dumpling Haus. It's basically a quick stop for dumplings and noodles. I ordered the pan fried dumplings, shrimp dumplings, and soup dumplings. Overall, it was nothing special but a nice place to eat if you have a craving for dim sum. The dumplings were balanced in flavor. My favorite was the soup dumpling.  The look, feel, and spaciousness of the restaurant gives off a great vibe. Space was well-taken care of and really clean. Customer Service was A+

Victor B. mostly nailed this one. I can't believe all the gushing reviews here. The food here is really terrible and despite the name you can get better dumplings in the frozen food aisle of any asian market.  We tried some bao zi (buns) and guo tie (potstickers) and the peanut noodles. Both the potstickers and the buns had the same extremely bland filling. We pulled the filling out of one and it also had an unappetizing rubbery texture.  Furthermore, the buns had a slightly yeasty flavor to their dough that neither of us enjoyed.  Oh and they served soy sauce mixed with ginger and some other herbs with our bao zi and our guo tie with nothing. This makes absolutely no sense and should obviously be swapped. Who puts soy sauce on their bao zi?  From there we moved on to the peanut noodles which were probably the best thing we had, but it required some work on our part. There is a chinese peanut noodle dish topped with a sweet soy sauce that I tried to replicate with normal soy sauce. It elevated it to edible which is more than I can say for the other dishes.  The biggest problem here though is the price. Peanut Noodles were noodles and some cucumber slices in a rather small serving size for 8 dollars. Our other items were similarly overpriced. You can get much better, though slightly unorthodox, potstickers at China Wok for close to 2/3 price and get a larger serving.  However, I give the place a lot of credit for its interior design. It's nice and bright and the bar setup really works for a place that serves their fare. Too bad their decor is let down by their product.

We stopped after a movie and had the shrimp salad with tofu which my friend found too salty, and too heavy on the tofu; the pork dumplings which were tender and tasty; the hot and sour soup which lacked depth and was too gelatinous; the shrimp dumplings which tasted old and fishy, and the wonton soup. In this, the broth was way too salty, but the wontons were tender and tasty. So out of five dishes, one and a half were good enough to go back for. But is that enough? Eh, maybe we'll try again. Maybe not.
Amazing dumplings, perfect place when you want either a small plate or a full bowl of noodles. Love this place!

I. Love. Dumpling. Haus. I have been going here for several years and never get tired of it. The food is delicious, the service is fairly fast, and it is easy to buy multiple things to share even between two people. It is an odd restaurant to have in a mall, but it makes it a hidden gem. Hilldale is now getting a make over so maybe Dumpling Haus will get a remodel, too. I highly recommend the meat-filled potstickers, veggie bao, and the house bao.

Not sure if they just didn't make a good batch, but my friends and I were not very impressed by this place :/ The service was fast and I liked the presentation of the food and the decor of the restaurant, so I wanted to like the food as well but it kinda fell short.  It's not bad by any means, but the food just didn't taste very 'well made'. I got the beef noodle soup...the noodles seemed low quality, the broth was quite bland, and the beef was alright.   The dumplings were a bit more redeeming, but still nothing to write home about in my opinion. I enjoyed my experience there but for the price, I don't think the quality was there.  If you're super into dumplings or want some hot soup, I'd still hit this place up, and maybe your experience will be a bit better than mine! Overall, not a bad place, but I'm not sure if I'll be returning.

I stopped in here last month for a quick lunch while shopping, after reading a bunch of positive reviews here. I'm finally posting my unfinished draft in finished form. My impressions are as follows...  The good:  Really low chairs at the tables, for less messy noodle slurping Gluten free options in noodles and dumplings Ordering is done at the counter, but signs inform that no self-table-bussing is required Condiments all at hand in one spot: water, chopsticks, silverware, napkins Quiet and bright, bar seats available Open kitchen, you can watch it all being prepared  The meh: Coke products Ground and formed kibble-like pork bits. For $8.50, I expected real pork pieces or slices in my spicy pork noodle bowl. Flavors are good, but average, fairly "comfort foodish"; no dramatic standout flavors. I have a feeling they cater heavily to parents with little kids/elderly clientele, based on my fellow diners and the somewhat bland flavor of the food. I added rice vinegar, white pepper and chili sauce to make my soup taste like more than just vaguely oniony pork broth with noodles. Green shreds of what was called cabbage on the menu board, but was more like a sparse parsley garnish in appearance and amount, were the only other things in the bowl.  Marconi lights hang from red cords, Swedish modern tables and chairs, spare but comfortable layout and design and low music volume make a pleasant dining space.   I'll come again another time and try some other entrees.

Some people may think my rating of four stars for DumplingHaus is too high, but let me explain.  DumplingHaus is located in Madison, Wisconsin, which -after living for about five years there- is not a city known for Dim Sum, let alone tasty Chinese food. Although the city has increased the number of Chinese restaurants since I've lived there, it still is far less than other large mid-western cities. That's why DumplingHaus' prices are so high. There's no competition!  I rolled up into DumplingHaus with my Asian crew, and we got dumpling wasted! Where was DumplingHaus during my college career? Below are the dishes we feasted on:  Shrimp Dumplings - Very tasty, but I don't think I would order it again.  Pork Shaomai - The pan-fried dumplings stuffed with pork, veggies, ginger, and scallions were delicious. I regret not eating more.   Wonton Soup - Solid dumplings with a very tasty (and not too salty) broth. This is perhaps the biggest surprise I had eating here. A small serving for the price.  Barbecue Bao - The bun filled with roasted barbecue pork was good, but not great.  4 Servings of Xiao Long Bao - The soup dumplings filled with pork and ginger were very good. So good, that after the initial serving, we ordered three more. For only the Xiao Long Bao, that's 32 total dumplings. *Note: Be careful when eating. The soup in the dumpling will burn your mouth.  Overall, all of the dumplings and bao are great. After our meal, we had an opportunity to speak the owners. I asked them if the dumplings were fresh, and they said that they make their dumplings from scratch the day before. They are then put in the freezer at night so they are ready to be steamed the next day before being served.   The food isn't the best that I've ever had, but given that it's Madison, WI, it would be difficult to find a better place. But that's not to take anything away from DumplingHaus. The food is delicious, and I wish there was several of them in the Twin Cities!   I would get my fix every week.

My (teen) daughter and I had a wonderful dinner - both loved it.  Our meal Haus (Pot) Stickers, Haus Noodle Soup, Black Bean & Pork Soup, and Beef Curry Bao, The often picky teen  made happy-eating noises all through dinner and talked about her Haus Noodle (with pork and veggies) soup all evening and into the next day.  I was impressed with the Bao which was really fluffy and flavorful, but also substantial and made a great meal. Haus Sticker dumplings were good and the Black Bean & Pork soup which was okay but didn't wow me with flavor (I was also disappointed that it was not a broth soup, but noodles with a black bean and ground pork "sauce" - served "spaghetti-style" for lack of a better analogy with a thickish "sauce" over noodles).  It was our first time there, so didn't realize that each dish whether a dumpling, bao or soup is basically a meal's worth so ended up over ordering - on the upside, we have lunch again today.  Would be a good place to go with several friends (tho beware limited seating) and just share several plates.  Owners are very nice and friendly. Will go again!

The dumplings I ordered were so good! I got one with beef and one with pork and that was really the only difference in taste even thought they were separate menu items. Totally NOT complaining though because they were delicious and even though I went yesterday, I want to go back today. ADDICTED.

MOAR BAO ZI. MOAR.  Despite the super anglicized name, DumplingHaus seems to be a typical mom-and-pop Chinese restaurant. The adorable gentleman at the cash register reminded me of my grandfather, really! So much so that I was THIS close to ordering my food in Chinese...but I could only really read half of the Chinese text on the menu so I didn't want to make a fool of myself.   Anyway, I didn't have very high expectations for the food (seriously now, who would expect a place called "DumplingHaus" to provide high-quality, authentic Chinese food?!), so there wasn't much for the restaurant to live up to.   I ordered the cold peanut noodles and a plate of veggie bao zi. Neither of the dishes was very complex, and I am 110% positive that the veggie bao zi came from some plastic bag from a frozen foods aisle, but I'm not complaining - they hit the spot!   I've since picked up some veggie bao zi from a local grocery store, so I probably won't be back any time soon, but it is good to know that a Chinese restaurant like this exists in Madison!

Honeydew tea is very refreshing!  I love this place because it is so different.  It is authentic.  It is not my usual burger or pizza place...well, mostly because it has neither of those items.  But it does have a great variety of noodle dishes, dumplings (hence the name) and well, other stuff I have not tried.  When I feel adventurous I like to go here.  It is pretty sad that red bean paste is me stepping out of my comfort zone but it is good!  Everything is really clean and efficient as well.  We got our food within 10 minutes and it is all really fresh.  Good prices as well!  4 dumplings was $8 and then 8 wontons, a soup and the tea all added up to be less than $20.  Nom nom nom...
So delicious! As a vegetarian, they have great options for me. I really love the veggie bao & Nutella bao!

So I finally made it to the DumplingHaus. Tucked away near Macy's in Hilldale mall with a very German name is not where one would expect to get some good dumplings - but here we are all the same!   The whole place feels very modern with a red and white Ikea/Crate & Barrel feel...it's set up like a standard fast casual restaurant. Order, they have everything written on a board as well as a bunch of specials!  Once you decide grab a table and set yourself up. Grab some utensils, chili garlic sauce, soy sauce (if you need), and some napkins. Have a 5 minute conversation and your order will be served up - piping hot!  We tried the House Bao as well as the Xiao Long Bao. They both were amazing. I loved the Xiao long bao - the ginger really came through. I do think they could have included more soup and they were not served with the correct spoon - but this is minor note as I was having soup dumplings in Madison!   The House Bao had a light and fluffy dumpling quality with a very good quantity of filling. I loved dunking it in the vinegar with a little of the chili garlic sauce - so good!  This place became crowded quickly but turnover is also pretty good so not too bad of a wait at any given time. A lot of people had noodle bowls so next time I will get some of that action. But as far as the dumplings go - yum!

My boyfriend, Mom and I stopped in here for a quick lunch on a Saturday afternoon. We heard good things and figured we would give it a try while in the area. The seating was limited  around 2:30 pm but we managed to find a table for 3.  I honestly didn't spend enough time reading the menu and kind of just ordered based on the vegetarian recommendation of the guy running the register. He was very nice and tried to offer me several items that he thought were great. I settled on the peanut glaze bowl and veggie wontons for us to share. My company both got the black bean and pork dish.  None of us were really impressed with our noodle bowls. In my opinion they should have more veggies otherwise it's just too much noodle for my taste. Mine was garnished with cucumber slivers but not enough to add any flavor. Broccoli would have been nice. Their bowls were bland too, and I think the pork should be sliced and not tiny chunks like another person mentioned.  The wontons were okay but I have had better. I think they were filled with just seaweed or possibly spinach? Couldn't tell but the dipping sauce was good.  All in all, I was pretty sad that I spent $27 dollars there for 2 of us to eat (I paid for two meals and the wontons). I left wishing I had spent that money at Noodles and Co. or anywhere else for that matter. I don't live in the area so I won't be back, but it's possible they have other items on the menu I would enjoy.

"This is going on our regular rotation." Wisdom from my oh so critical boyfriend as he slurped up Peanut Glazed Noodled and Jin Xiao steamed dumplings. When it came to the Nutella Bao, however, there were no words. Just small mutterred sounds of happiness and yeah ok, some silly sound effect as we played with the pillowy bounceable Bao. Go. Its a casual atmosphere. Wear your sweats and dive in to comfort food.
We love this noodle soup and dumpling place. My daughter and I come her to share awesome comfort food

This place is incredible! I had the Haus noodles with beef and it was delicious! 10/10 would recommend! The food is incredibly authentic according to my companion who had just been in China for 6 months. He had missed the dumplings and was very satisfied with what they offered. Beware though that bones are kept in many of the dishes because that is how it is traditionally served in China. They also do quick and easy takeout!

This place is such a hidden treasure. I still stop there when I come back to Madison (I live in Chicago) because I'm straight up addicted to the Harvest Vegetable Soup. It's a simple soup that basically tastes how a warm hug feels, if noodles and baby bok choy were involved. There are many other great things on the menu too, like their dumplings (of course). The prices are a bit high, but you can tell from the flavors that they use high-quality, fresh ingredients, so for me it's worth it.

I've been twice this month.  A pretty good sign that I dig it.  And although I've oft compared dumplings to lovely lady food, the place is filling.  I will agree with many who've said the prices are high given the ingredients, but I'm happy to pay for things that take a gentle hand. I wouldn't dare try stuffing delicious meat and veg into a small pocket, sealing that up, then lightly pan frying it. No way. And so I'm glad someone else has it down. I do with the menu was more protein rich, but on my last trip, I discovered you can take whatever protein they have and add that to whatever dish you like. So for example, if the spicy noodles get you going but you'd like some chicken... ask them. They seem happy to accommodate.

I can't explain how much I wanted to love DumplingHaus and I was so excited to try out their new location. I have such a soft spot for dumplings, bar, and noodles and the fact that DumplingHaus offers all of it in one place is enough for my heart to soar. While the place itself has open tables, decent ambiance, and easy ordering from the counter, the food itself just didn't deliver for me.   I tried the cold Peanut Glazed Noodles and while it was a good sized portion for $8, there just wasn't enough flavor for me. The noodles were a little overcooked and heavy, and while it was something I could eat with no problem, I just didn't feel like I wanted to keep going.  We also ordered the Xiao Long Bao - they came out hot and looked like the perfect pockets of heaven I know them to be. Now, the best/most challenging part of eating XLB is picking them up with your chopsticks without breaking them and delivering it to a spoon successfully, the ones here were a whole new level of difficulty. They really stuck to the dish and more than half of ours broke, no matter how gingerly we picked them up. The meat inside was also a frightening pink color. The taste was fine, nothing phenomenal but I was a little heartbroken over the experience.  Overall, I think DumplingHaus has a lot to offer but needs some adjustments to get there. I think I would return just because no other place really offers some of their items readily, but I hope they take a look at some of the reviews and get DumplingHaus to the level of stardom I know it can be!

DumplingHaus is a small little Dim Sum shop in the outdoor/indoor mall in Madison and is a pretty small, great little place for lunch if you're in the area.  It's more than just a few notches better than any food court stall, and serves decent Asian dishes really, really quickly!    Since this was my first time there, my friend and I went all out, and ordered the cilantro-tomato soba, shrimp dumplings (can't remember their official name), the Haus Buns and the Barbecue Pork Buns.  For me, the shrimp dumplings were the best part, covered perfectly in a wrapper and really vibrant with shrimp-y shellfish-y flavor.  There was maybe 8 of them in a classic dim sum steamer and man, they were just excellent!  The dipping sauce that came with them only served to amplify their deliciousness to the next level.  On the other hand, the buns were sadly a huge disappointment.  I came in expecting them to be housemade, but after taking a bite out of them, I knew immediately they came from a classic frozen package of buns you can find in practically any good Asian market.  The flavor was fine, but having made bao like these before from local markets, I knew immediately it wasn't quite what I had dreamed of.  Sadly since 3 barbecue pork buns were something like $6.95 at the restaurant, I couldn't help but feel ripped off since a frozen bag of 12 or so cost a few bucks less than that if you were to actually buy them at a grocery.  All that said, it was still a nice experience, the food came out quickly, and the staff was very friendly.  Maybe the extra cost isn't so bad when you know you're paying for the quick convenience of it all!

Very good place for Chinese dumplings, in Madison. Small soup dumplings are delicious. The guy at the counter is not surly as another reviewer said, but simply a normal Chinese restaurant guy. It is also not true that the prices are not posted. You pay first at the counter and cash register,and then they bring your order to your table. Highly recommended, if what you want is Chinese style dumplings, and you happen to be in Madison Wisconsin.

Right up front, I need to say that, despite a lot of gastronomical adventurousness that I have, it does not translate to Chinese food.  I like Chinese food, but I always eat the same thing--potstickers.  My wife introduced me to the Dumpling Haus a couple of months ago.  Wow!  The ingredients are fresh, you can watch them prepare their food, and it comes out fast.  I freakin' love this place.  It may not be the absolute greatest food I have had, but if I am going to have Chinese food, this is the first and last place I am going in Madison.  Noodles and dumplings!  This place was made for me.

I've been here twice in the last week. I'm probably going to shoot for three. That alone should tell you what you need to know about it.   The bao are simply amazing. I insist you try the taco bao, even if it scares you a little. It's fresh, crisp, and amazing. The flavors are perfect. When I ordered it with my husband, he turned his nose up at the idea like a 3 year old presented with Brussel sprouts. I'd had them before, so I knew he would be proven very wrong in his assumption. I was right. He got to try a bite of mine, and attempted to steal the whole thing. I had to fend him off with a chopstick. I've also had the beef curry bao and the BBQ beef and pork. All very good, but that taco bao...  My husband ordered the peanut noodles, something an allergy prevents me from eating. I had to sit across from him while he raved about how awesome they were. *Please note I ordered these to go for him when I went back without him. They do **not** reheat well, but are good cold*   It can get a little pricey if you order a couple of different things, but is well worth it. Try the honeydew iced tea!

I'm a sucker for dumplings of any variety, and these are among the best in town. I've been here about 6 times in the past 4 months and look forward to every visit.  Xiao Long Bao is the perfect food - soup dumplings with great sauce, ideal texture, and served at the right temperature. Bao Zi are also good - the Barbecue one has great filling. Noodle bowls slay - only other place in town that's nearly as good is Umami. Everything I've had on the menu has been top notch.  Low-key interior, usually very clean, staff always friendly, and the price is right. Lately for lunch I've been getting Xiao Long Bao and a soda and with tip it is about $11. I'd come here during shopping at Hilldale, before a movie at Sundance, or (as I do), for lunch during work. It is a bit crowded during the noon hour, but I've never had to wait for a table.

I had worked part time at Hilldale Mall, so I have been to this establishment many times.  I had tried to find something to LOVE at Dumpling Haus but I wasn't wowed by anything.  The Veggie Noodle Soup is nice, especially during the cold season.  The potstickers are nice but not super special.  I just didn't get excited about the Dumpling Haus as a destination.  I have a friend who lives and dies for the peanut noodles with chicken served cold.  So that means I ended up there more than I wanted.  But during the Wisconsin Film Festival, I grabbed the Curry Beef Bao on a whim.  OMG, it is so flavorful and delish!  The fluffy bun is a nice contrast to the slight kick of the curry ground beef.  I have had it a few times since early April and it has not disappointed.  I have finally found my go-to item at the Dumpling Haus.  :)  Side note:  The family that runs this business is so nice and helpful.  They are the real reason I have eaten there as much as I have.  This is a local business that deserves to keep growing.

Used to like this place.However today... very poor value for the money. Prices are no longer posted, it appears that the old guy at the counter makes up the numbers as he writes down your order.and surprise surprise .. No printed receipt... hmmmm  How legal is that? No posted prices, no receipt.  Never coming back.

I brought my friends from China here and they were blown away to find such traditional Chinese food in Wisconsin. I was so happy they loved it! And I did too!!! Beautifully decorated and in a great location. The menu was even written in Chinese and English. There is even a viewing window of the chef cooking!!! So cool!
The best baozi in Madison! I like to have bao and noodles there, especially in the morning. If you want to try some Chinese special, you should go there.

I rave about this place all the time by word of mouth, so it's about time I put it online. Any place that serves authentic xiao long bao is a rare gem in the U.S. The delicious dumplings are served directly in a metal steamer and there is that unbelievably rich soup that bursts out after your first bite. Mmmmm...just like the ones in Hangzhou and Shanghai.  The dessert buns, house dumplings and all the other items on the menu are delicious too. Nothing is drenched in corn starch or fried. This is good 'ole northern China cookin' right in Madison! The cooking staff is straight from Beijing and makes all the wrappers by hand from scratch. Prices are a bit high if you want to be really full because it's hard to just order 1 of anything here. The Asian drink selection is great too. All around awesome place right in Midvale Mall, where there's ample parking.

After eating here, I feel a little unsatisfied.  The food tastes good but it doesn't quite hit the spot!  The "Haus Stickers" are tasty but don't have a great enough contrast between crispier bottom of the dumpling and the inside. To me, that's one of the best parts about the dumpling.  If you want something more virtuous, the Seasonal Veggie soup has broth, noodles, and vegetables, good for a cold day or if you're feeling a bit under the weather.  Super light flavored broth--again, it feels a little lacking in complexity.   The employees are charming and it's a good quick option in Hilldale but more flavor and texture is necessary to lure me to the Haus.
Great dumplings much cheaper and less pretentious than the hipster place across town.
small, quick, and good = my kind of place. shrimp dumplings and sesame noodle kick were awesome. wish I could take this place home with me.
Delicious veggie dumplings. Quick service. My go to place for take out when traveling between the hospital and west clinic. People are also very friendly.

Great food in a neat location. I got the mix of the buns and each of them was amazing. The noodles are made fresh and the noodle bowl was huge! It's a bit pricy but you get a lot of food. The guy taking my order reminded me of an Asian version of my grandpa and he was sure to check on my satisfaction. It was adorable. I would come back here for dinner but there was too much food for me for lunch.

We were visiting from out of town and wanted ramen. Through Yelp, this was the closest location. Not knowing what to expect, off we went. When we realized it was in the mall we were a bit skeptical. Since we really wanted ramen and we had limited time, we went for it.   What a surprise!  While they did not have traditional ramen, they did have noodle soup. The dashi (soup base) was perfect. Not too salty and flavorful. We added on pork shumai and shrimp dumplings. They were excellent as well.   The atmosphere was simple being a mall restaurant, but the food was great.  We could see where the food was being prepared from scratch, which was a nice add. We would go back next time we are in town.

We love dumpling haus! We were here two days in a row a couple weeks ago. My son loves their shrimp dumplings. Their house dumplings and soup dumplings a really good too. The wrappers are very delicate not too doughy with just enough filling. The sauce they come with is super yummy too (make sure to get the hot chili oil on the back counter).   Their noodle dishes are really good too. My husband likes the sesame noodle kick and I love the black bean and pork noodles. Taste very traditional like you would get in Chicago's Chinatown.  Service is also excellent. The gentleman at the front counter is always super nice to our son and gives him an extra fortune cookie. The prices are a little high; if you start to order noodle dishes plus dumplings you bill can get quite high. But they are located in Hilldale and rent is probably through the roof and the food is always amazing so I don't mind paying a little more for good quality.

The Best: The Sesame Kick Noodle and Xiao Long Bao (???) also known as soup dumplings are a winning combination that will have you coming back again and again! I've taken several of my friends here with this combo and no one has been disappointed yet. Certainly one of my more favorite Asian style comfort food place. Highly recommend!   Side-bar: do you know how to eat soup dumplings? Place one dumpling in spoon being very careful of not ripping the skin. Dip the dumpling in the delicious sauce, and nibble the corner of the dumpling. Drink all the savory soup and then eat the rest of the dumpling!   Other Food: Bao zis (??) are okay, black bean and pork has a creamier texture that can also be enjoyable. Other dishes are good but get the winning combo if you want something delish!   Services: Water, napkins, and utensils are self-serve. Speed is usually pretty quick, depending on how busy it is. Would estimate ~10 minutes from order time.  Other: restaurant is family-ran, restaurant owners are from Bei-Jing I believe but their menu features dishes that are specialities from different cities like Shanghai and Southern provinces.

Never had dumplings like these before! Lightly steamed and filled with all wonderfully spiced fillings-- too hard to decide which tasted the best!! It was a great place to get a quick bite to eat while shopping the Hilldale shops. Enjoy the time here!!
Potstickers are not very tasty, yet the veggie Baozi is not bad. Veggie tofu is a relatively authentic Chinese food.

Pretty tasty food in a nice setting in the Hilldale Mall.  The bao were sweeter than I thought they would be and the dishes we had were saltier than I was expecting.  I had the Spicy Sesame Chicken Salad and my fiancee had the Black Bean and Pork Noodle Bowl.  Service was friendly.  Definitely worth a trip.

I finally got to taste their shrimp dumpling. And it was okay. The sauce was not my favorite at all.  I'd give it the benefit of a doubt so I may try other menu and might have a different opinion. As for now, a three-star rate is sufficient.
It's pretty good. My favorite dish would be the Taco Bao! You gotta have it!
Good for a quick noodle dish and the only place I know of in Madison that serves a big variety of dumplings/steamed buns.

Dumpling Haus is by far one of the best places to get Chinese food in Madison. While their menu is more limited than other restaurants, it just proves that they keep fresh, quality ingredients around. I spent a summer in China recently, and the food here reminds me of the quality food you find in those random hole in the wall restaurants. I am definitely making it my summer goal to try everything on the menu!
